revision.text:
{{italic title}} {{Taxobox | name = ''Mycocepurus castrator'' | image = | image_caption = | regnum = [[Animal]]ia | phylum = [[Arthropod]]a | classis = [[Insect]]a | ordo = [[Hymenoptera]] | subordo = [[Apocrita]] | superfamilia = [[Vespoidea]] | familia = [[Formicidae]] | subfamilia = [[Myrmicinae]] | tribus = [[Attini]] | genus = ''[[Mycocepurus]]'' | species = '''''M. castrator''''' | binomial = ''Mycocepurus castrator'' | binomial_authority = Rabeling & Bacci, 2010<ref name="Rabeling&Bacci_2010">{{cite journal |last=Rabeling |first=Christian |last2=Bacci Jr. |first2=Maurício |date=July 2010 |title=A new workerless inquiline in the Lower Attini (Hymenoptera: Formicidae), with a discussion of social parasitism in fungus-growing ants |url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1365-3113.2010.00533.x/abstract |journal=[[Systematic Entomology]] |publisher=[[Wiley-Blackwell]] |volume=35 |issue=3 |pages=379–392 |doi=10.1111/j.1365-3113.2010.00533.x |accessdate=26 August 2014 |subscription=yes }}</ref> }} '''''Mycocepurus castrator''''' is a [[species]] of [[Parasitism|parasitic]] [[ant]], in the genus ''[[Mycocepurus]]'', native to [[Brazil]].<ref name="Smithsonian">{{cite web |url=http://smithsonianscience.org/2014/08/new-species-ant-offers-compelling-evidence-controversial-theory-species-formation/ |title=Discovery: Deadbeat ant species branched off as parasite inside its own colony |date=21 August 2014 |website=Smithsonian Science |accessdate=26 August 2014 }}</ref> Described in 2010, the species is a workerless and [[obligate parasite]] of the related ant ''[[Mycocepurus goeldii]]''. It is known only from [[Rio Claro, São Paulo|Rio Claro]], Brazil, and has only been found in nests of ''M. goeldii''.
''M. castrator'' and its [[Host (biology)|host]] are closely related and diverged recently, around 37,000 years ago. They evolved in the same geographic region, making the parasite–host pair an example of [[sympatric speciation]]. The species is the first [[inquiline]] known among the lower [[Attini|attines]].
==Etymology== Because ''M. goeldii'' [[Ant colony|nests]] that host ''M. castrator'' appear to only produce sterile workers, the species has been named "[[wikt:castrator|castrator]]" in reference to that.<ref name="Rabeling&Bacci_2010" />
==Description== ''M. castrator'' is a relatively minuscule species, with the average wing length being about 1.07–1.23 millimeters. The head is rectangular in shape, measuring about 0.6 millimeters across the face. The [[Antenna (biology)|antennae]] consist of 11 segments. The species has stout, sharp, [[Propodeum|propodeal]] spines. The body, which ranges between light and dark reddish-brown, is thinly covered in [[seta]]e. The body surface is shiny and patterned with tiny hexagonal structures.<ref name="Rabeling&Bacci_2010" />
Unlike most species of ''[[Mycocepurus]]'', males and females are physically similar. Distinguishing characteristics include the [[Mandible (insect mouthpart)|mandibles]]; the mandible terminates in a tooth in females, but does not do so in males. The first [[:wikt:gastric|gastric]] [[tergite]] is only slightly concave in males, but markedly so in females. Finally, males' wings are medium to dark brown.<ref name="Rabeling&Bacci_2010" />
The species is not believed to have a worker caste.<ref name="Rabeling&Bacci_2010" />
==Habitat and distribution== ''M. castrator'' has only been observed in nests on the grounds of the [[São Paulo State University]] in [[Rio Claro, São Paulo|Rio Claro]], [[São Paulo (state)|São Paulo]], Brazil.<ref name="Rabeling et al. 2014" /> It has only been found in nests of ''M. goeldii'', which is a widely distributed species, known from Brazil to northern [[Argentina]]. Like many other inquilines, ''M. castrator'' has small and isolated populations.<ref name="Rabeling&Bacci_2010" />
==Natural history== Described in 2010, ''M. castrator'' is a social [[obligate parasite]] and the first [[inquiline]] known among the lower [[fungus-growing ants|attines]]. The [[sex ratio]] for the species is skewed strongly toward females, with a ratio of about 11 to 1. The species is [[Host (biology)|host]]-tolerant, with [[wikt:dealate|dealate]] [[Queen ant|queens]] of the species being found in the same nest chambers as queens of ''M. goeldii''. However, it also inhibits its host's reproduction, preventing the production of fertile offspring.<ref name="Rabeling&Bacci_2010" />
==Behavior== ===Interaction with host species=== ''M. goeldii'' workers will feed ''M. castrator'' queens in a process called [[trophallaxis]]. The two species will also engage in [[social grooming|grooming]] each other, with dealate ''M. castrator'' queens frequently climbing on top of ''M. goeldii'' workers and queens.<ref name="Rabeling&Bacci_2010" />
Host workers have also been observed to attack and kill parasite queens.<ref name="Rabeling&Bacci_2010" />
==Reproduction== ''M. castrator'' is [[gyne|polygynous]] (nests consisting of multiple queens).<ref name="Rabeling&Bacci_2010" /> The species mates inside the nest, as opposed to engaging in a [[nuptial flight]] like most ants.<ref name="Rabeling et al. 2014" /> During mating, males and females copulate seemingly at random, with copulation lasting 18 to 27 seconds on average. Female [[alate]]s begin to lose their wings three hours after mating, after which they congregate and engage in social grooming. Males begin to die twelve hours after mating.<ref name="Rabeling&Bacci_2010" />
==Relationship to ''Mycocepurus goeldii''== ''M. castrator'' is directly descended from ''M. goeldii'', its host. Such relationships are not uncommon among social parasites, as recognized by [[Emery's rule]]. Less common are cases like ''M. castrator'''s, where two species diverge without the benefit of geographic isolation, known as [[sympatric speciation]]. Rabeling ''et al.'' (2014) analyzed divergence of [[Mitochondrial DNA|mitochondrial]] versus [[Nuclear DNA|nuclear]] [[DNA]], finding that the nuclear [[allele]]s bore more similarities than the mitochondrial alleles. This led them to rule out the possibility of recent [[Hybrid (biology)|interbreeding]], and conclude that sympatric speciation had occurred. The two species are believed to have diverged around 37,000 years ago, during the late [[Pleistocene]].<ref name="Rabeling et al. 2014">{{cite journal |last=Rabeling |first=Christian |last2=Schultz |first2=Ted R. |last3=Pierce |first3=Naomi E. |last4=Bacci Jr. |first4=Maurício |date=21 August 2014 |title=A Social Parasite Evolved Reproductive Isolation from Its Fungus-Growing Ant Host in Sympatry |url=http://www.cell.com/current-biology/abstract/S0960-9822(14)00911-7 |journal=[[Current Biology]] |publisher=[[Cell Press]] |volume= |issue= |pages= |doi=10.1016/j.cub.2014.07.048 |accessdate=28 August 2014 |subscription=yes }}</ref>
